summary: Carrots scrubbed and peeled and brined, now awaiting their microbial transformation! Pickled carrots are so good. (After I took the photo I added a weight to submerge the pokey ones).

Is it really a ‚Äúbirth-rate crisis‚Äù when we have nearly 8 billion people? One article quote: ‚ÄúFewer people are good for the climate, but the economic consequences are severe.‚Äù Can‚Äôt they hear how ridiculous this sounds? ‚ÄúKeep driving off the cliff; braking might stall the car.‚Äù

name: Hugo puzzlement
summary:
So this Hugo online notebook idea (I describe the idea here) is proving to be a challenge. I‚Äôve read a few pages about index.md vs. _index.md, and as someone who has never coded or worked with computers past being a user of apps, it all feels like a foreign language. I can‚Äôt deciper what this page means, or this one. This person seems confused too but he must have a background in coding because he read the previous stuff and that clarified things for him.
My theme doesn‚Äôt seem to render the pages properly (I‚Äôm using Digital Garden). I don‚Äôt know enough about this to tell whether it‚Äôs the theme that‚Äôs the issue, or just the way I‚Äôve structured things, but basically the problem is that I create a folder and I want the base index page to exist (I know enough HTML to know that index.html is the default page in a folder that the browser loads), but apparently sometimes with Hugo you use _index.md? But I can‚Äôt tell when. The instructions seem to say, ‚ÄúIf folders come after (are nested inside) this one, use _index.md for the uppermost folder,‚Äù but I have tested this and it doesn‚Äôt work. Sometimes the page loads a blank page, sometimes ‚ÄúPage Not Found,‚Äù but never the actual page that has the content on it.
Next steps:

Definitely finish the YouTube series from Mike Dane I was watching out on how to get started with Hugo.
Maybe figuring out what this whole TOML thing is, and how to use it, would help?
Keep working to finish the HTML and CSS course that I started awhile ago (chronic illness makes progress slow). I feel like this could help a lot in understanding layout, but it still feels like there are many concepts integral to computing in general, that I don‚Äôt recognize or understand. When I watch YouTube tutorials, it‚Äôs clear there are foundational ideas that people assume you must know, that I don‚Äôt recognize.

Belated (by an hour or so) entry for Caturday. Here‚Äôs Cal duking it out with Princess Leia!
  
üêàüì∑
Today is game night, and my friend is sending me images of their new game, called Dog Park - we normally play with 7 but tonight we may have to team up lol!

My Hugo installation is up and running! Well, locally anyway, it‚Äôs nowhere online. Am now learning how to use it. How fun! I would happily spend my life creating funky little archival websites/blogs of weird little niche subjects.

Trying to install a Hugo blog. Okay, so what I need is language to do a search that will help me find pages or books or videos to describe the most basic things, like the concept of a terminal, what it does, what yaml is and why that‚Äôs better than toml, and other mysteries that every YouTube video I can find takes for granted that one already knows.
I‚Äôve got programmer/coding friends all over the place (spreads out hands - BEHOLD, YE BEAUTIFUL NERDS) but whenever I ask these super basic things, I get amused befuddlement, it‚Äôs like those are the things people learned first, at the start. For many of you that was back in the 80‚Äôs or 90‚Äôs (or 70‚Äôs) and you don‚Äôt even remember how you absorbed those essential basic building blocks. You just did, they‚Äôre just in there.
I need the building blocks, but where do you get those in 2022? When you‚Äôre 48 years old? Where are all the fresh baby nerds starting out these days?

The Trader Joe‚Äôs help counter tells me they‚Äôre out of the autumnal apple caramels and the candied pumpkin seeds. After the weeping (okay really I just had a very stricken expression for several minutes) I did find these amazing new ice cream bars. Gluten free, yo!

The whole household is now bivalently boosted, but this one has hit harder than the last couple of vaccines. I‚Äôm grateful there‚Äôs nothing pressing to get done today. And of course: SO grateful for the vaccines themselves.

name: Takeout Night!
summary: We don‚Äôt go to restaurants anymore because of that pesky global pandemic, and that means I‚Äôve evolved into this person who gets just super bonkers excited over one of the fam going to pick up dinner and bring it home. I get the movie queued up, there is discussion about what beverages we need, etc. I do miss restaurants but I gotta say we have made the best of it! Getting takeout is truly fun.
Excellent pillow selection at our local hair salon

name: Jupiter can comic!
summary: Jupiter (our 17yo) was telling me about the art class they‚Äôre in at school and how the new assignment to do a comic-style piece felt frustrating because that just isn‚Äôt their usual style. So it blew me away to see their final piece! It‚Äôs amazing! The rules were no humans or anthropomorphic animals, no words, but one sound effect. They said they got inspiration from when we used to visit the Japanese Garden so much when we lived in Seattle. ‚ù§Ô∏è üé®

name: Some of my thoughts and difficulties figuring out whether to use ClassicPress or Micro.blog
summary:
My tale of starting Micro.blog, swapping over to ClassicPress, and ending back up on Micro.blog again
Early this year when I discovered IndieWeb, I thought it‚Äôd be fun to get back into blogging. Originally I assumed I‚Äôd use WordPress for this. I used WordPress in the early ‚Äò10‚Äôs when my kids were little, and I enjoyed it a lot. I made a handful of different cooking and craft blogs that petered out over time. When Gutenberg came along, I was not a fan (my thoughts echo this person‚Äôs), and I eventually moved more to using Facebook and off blogging entirely.
So I was excited to find out there is this magical marvelous thing called ClassicPress, a fork of pre-Gutenberg WordPress, now being lovingly tended by a community of people who wanted to keep that functionality alive. I love community-run projects like this.
Micro.blog vs. ClassicPress
Meanwhile, I had also gotten an early account on Micro.blog, without knowing much about it other than I loved the simple aesthetics. Now I was trying to read up on Micro.blog, learning what a static site generator was and what made it different from WordPress. I know a little HTML and CSS, but I don‚Äôt know anything about My SQL or PHP, sysadmin tasks, or any of the underlying parts of either site. But my smattering of HTML and CSS made Micro.blog seem like the better choice, because I would know how to begin modifying themes and tinkering. Tinkering in WordPress code had always been a disaster.
Initially, Micro.blog was hard for me beacause I couldn‚Äôt have comments from outside Micro.blog. I understand there is a thing called Brid.gy but I don‚Äôt fully understand how it works, and no one I know who isn‚Äôt in a tech field or has tech as one of their major hobbies (this describes 75% of my circle of friends), knows what web mentions are or how to use them.
This means that if I meet some nice people in, say, an online sewing group, and I give them a link to the latest skirt I just made, they will have no way to comment on the post I made. If the point of having a blog is to connect with people, then a blog that lacks the functionality for comments seems to discourage that.
But then ClassicPress turns out to be unsustainable
This past week (October, 2022) I was able to get my own installation of ClassicPress up and going. This felt great, I had some initial trouble but a wonderful person in the ClassicPress community hung out with me for about half an hour one night and helped me figure out how to get the database installed. Again - community is so important, in EVERYTHING, and I can‚Äôt say enough good things about the community support I‚Äôve received and seen in all three of these places I‚Äôve been exploring, IndieWeb, ClassicPress, and Micro.blog.
I installed some IndieWeb plug-ins that I barely understood, but after a page I made about my chronic illness received some nice comments on Twitter, those comments did show up on my ClassicPress blog, which was pretty cool. Woot!
But then‚Ä¶
However the problem with ClassicPress is that apparently most web hosts see it as an outdated version of WordPress. As it was explained to me, this makes sense from a security standpoint. Outdated apps offer up vulnerabilities that, when exploited, might affect more on the server than your site alone.
There are apparently a few web hosts who have an installer called Softaculous, which will install and maintain ClassicPress properly, eliminating these concerns, but from what I understand, these web hosts are hard to find. My web host is SiteGround, and they don‚Äôt have a Softaculous installer, and instead have an unfortunate history of auto-updating ClassicPress installations with the current version of WordPress, as happened to this guy a few months ago.
I read this thread but was encouraged by the fact that apparently he contacted SiteGround support, and got them to remove his site from auto-updates? That seemed easy enough. So after futzing around with my own ClassicPress installation at holliebutler.net and getting everything just the way I liked it, I contacted SiteGround.
But I got a totally different story. I wrote about that exchange in the ClassicPress forums, but the gist of it is, they won‚Äôt remove my site from auto-updates:
We strongly discourage hosting outdated installations for extended periods of time, which is why the Autoupdate tool allows for a WP version update to be skipped, but does not allow for the installation to be completely excluded from the autoupdate system.
This seems to go against that the other guy was told, but there didn‚Äôt seem to be anything I could do. This means my only option was to keep track of any WordPress version updates on my own, and then go into my settings buried in my SiteGround account, and turn off each individual update as it approached. This just isn‚Äôt sustainable. I‚Äôm coping with a chronic illness, my brain is often a bit fogged and I‚Äôm routinely out of energy to deal with mundane details like this; there‚Äôs no way I will remember to do this.
And as it turns out, I had already missed one! In my SiteGround settings, when I went to see how to turn off the updates, it had already updated my site to WordPress 6.0.1. BAH.
Back to Micro.blog I go
I was so frustrated when I saw this, at midnight last night, that I went to my domain host (here I will make a plug for Porkbun.com, I just moved my domains here and I‚Äôm loving them - great tech support!) and moved my domain to point to my Micro.blog. I moved over the couple pages that I‚Äôd made so those links would still work. Once it was moved, I felt relief. I don‚Äôt have to stress about Micro.blog. I can add posts, I can tinker when I want or leave it alone for months, and it‚Äôs going to keep working whether I‚Äôm staring at it or not. The community around here is vibrant and the crew in charge is always thinking up new ways to make it better.
The only downside to Micro.blog, for me personally, is that lack of comments from outside the system. I was able to set up Reply by Email, a great plug-in by @sod, and I‚Äôm hoping that will get some use.
But my perspective on comments has changed a bit through all this. I remember when we were all blogging fifteen years ago, I knew dozens of folks at the time with WordPress blogs similar to mine, and it was true that we had a great time posting comments to each other. But spam - and occasionally harassing comments - was also a problem that had to be dealt with, and that took time I didn‚Äôt enjoy giving up. These days, with fewer blogs and fewer people commenting to them, it doesn‚Äôt feel as urgent to have that functionality. In my sewing group example, it‚Äôs likely that someone would comment on my link within the group rather than at the blog, anyway. So overall I‚Äôve become less concerned about whether a lack of comments will necessarily mean a lack of connection.
Other upsides include:

Much less expensive than SiteGround ($10/month for my Premium plan at Micro.blog vs. $25/month at SiteGround)
Easy to use MarsEdit for publishing (I could never get MarsEdit to work with my WordPress installations)
With the Premium account, friends and family can subscribe to my newsletter (once I‚Äôd lost JetPack I couldn‚Äôt find a way to enable that functionality with ClassicPress)
The option of podcasting if I ever want to play with that idea (part of the Premium account)
Tinkerable code

So here I am!
I‚Äôm hoping I can get some friends interested in blogging and getting their own Micro.blog accounts. :)

name: Inktober Day 11
summary:
Okay this is hastily done in every sense of the word, but in my defense I spent the better part of the day dealing with a benign but still stressful medical event and I find hospitals exhausting (just the experience; not the staff who were all wonderful), so I did this while drooping with fatigue at 8:30 pm.
I used¬† this photo as a model, and it‚Äôs supposed to be shrieking¬† ‚ÄúINKTOBER #11‚Äù and then ‚ÄúHappy National Coming Out Day!‚Äù I‚Äôve never used watercolors in a Molskine sketchbook though and wow, that didn‚Äôt take very well.
Ah well! Tomorrow‚Äôs Inktober theme is FORGET, so we can forget about Tuesday.
¬†

name: ClassicPress is fun!
summary:
This is me messing around with ClassicPress. Yes, I‚Äôve gone back in time and I‚Äôm blogging like it‚Äôs 2010 again. If you know me personally, you‚Äôre probably asking, ‚ÄúHa ha, which blog from 2010?‚Äù
There were several. I had a blog problem. I really liked starting new projects (that hasn‚Äôt changed). I‚Äôm not sure what this will be, if anything. But here we are.
I‚Äôm interested in the IndieWeb, and I want personal websites to be more accessible to people. You know, in case anyone decides to make one again. I have a lot of thoughts about how difficult that is for the average non-techie person, and I‚Äôm interested in making it less difficult.
I‚Äôm not sure how to do that, and I‚Äôm not sure ClassicPress is the way to get there ‚Äì not many non-techie folks I know could figure out how to get this installed without a lot of help. But maybe? I think it could be made easier.
For now, it‚Äôs an awful lot of fun for me. The original WordPress evokes much nostalgia!

name: Typos galore
summary: I don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs happening but I‚Äôm making typos over and over today. Last night I (temporarily) stopped using my iMac and moved entirely to my laptop instead, maybe that‚Äôs it? I checked and the keyboards are the same size. Maybe different clickablenesses or something (that‚Äôs not in the dictionary, but it‚Äôs a word).

Alright my pretties, which one of you wants to be a hat?

name: Fall is stationary season
summary: I don‚Äôt know what it is about fall, but I get an insatiable craving to start a new journal and/or bullet journal, or a new traveler‚Äôs journal, and then of course the fountain pens, and the washi tape. I‚Äôve turned so many people onto jetpens.com during the months of September and October. I love it when I ask someone if they‚Äôve heard of the website and they say no, and I can wax rhapsodic.

Little miss little miss little miss
Food be gone
Ain‚Äôt nobody gonna fill your bowl
When you meow your wrongs
Little miss little miss little miss
FOOD BE GONE
How you‚Äôre gonna howl
to get into another one of
these ‚Äúmy cat be wrong‚Äù songs
üì∑ üêà

It‚Äôs the toe beans that get me.
üì∑
üêà

I love these flowers that go all gothic when autumn comes. Other flowers die off, but this one just sticks around, puts on The Cure and tucks in.
üì∑üå±

My entire family has just converged to enthusiastically discuss game theory while standing in my kitchen as I‚Äôm trying to make homemade granola bars, and this is exactly the sort of moments I so love and will so miss having regularly, when the kids move out someday.

‚ÄúAnd the armor that should rest upon your shoulders, weighs upon your soul.‚Äù

Galadriel, heckin poetic elf

I‚Äôve been helping a young friend with adulting stuff, and now I want to create a curriculum for high school students with classes like Understanding Taxes, Finding a Doctor, Organizing Email and Other Paperwork, etc. The world is complex when you‚Äôre fresh out of high school.
